articles.title: Russian Emotional Support Phrases: Comfort Your Partner in Difficult Times
articles.content:
When your Russian-speaking partner faces difficult times, offering comfort in their native language reaches their *dusha* (soul). Russian's emotional depth makes it perfect for heartfelt support.

## Phrases of Presence

**–Ø —Ä—è–¥–æ–º**
*(Ya rya-dom)*
*I'm here*

**–¢—ã –Ω–µ –æ–¥–∏–Ω/–æ–¥–Ω–∞ –≤ —ç—Ç–æ–º**
*(Ty nye a-din/ad-na v e-tom)*
*You're not alone in this*

**–¢—ã –≤—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞ –º–æ–∂–µ—à—å –Ω–∞ –º–µ–Ω—è —Ä–∞—Å—Å—á–∏—Ç—ã–≤–∞—Ç—å**
*(Ty vseg-da mo-zhesh na me-nya ras-chi-ty-vat')*
*You can always count on me*

## Expressing Empathy

**–Ø –ø–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞—é, —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —á—Ç–æ —Ç—ã –ø—Ä–æ—Ö–æ–¥–∏—à—å**
*(Ya po-ni-ma-yu, che-rez chto ty pro-kho-dish)*
*I understand what you're going through*

**–≠—Ç–æ –Ω–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ —Ç–∞–∫ —Å–µ–±—è —á—É–≤—Å—Ç–≤–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å**
*(E-to nor-mal'-no tak se-bya chuv-stvo-vat')*
*It's normal to feel this way*

**–¢–≤–æ–∏ —á—É–≤—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –∞–±—Å–æ–ª—é—Ç–Ω–æ –ø–æ–Ω—è—Ç–Ω—ã**
*(Tvo-i chuv-stva ab-so-lyut-no po-nyat-ny)*
*Your feelings are completely understandable*

## Offering Comfort

**–í—Å—ë –±—É–¥–µ—Ç —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–æ**
*(Fsyo bu-det kho-ro-sho)*
*Everything will be okay*

**–í–º–µ—Å—Ç–µ –º—ã —Å–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏–º—Å—è**
*(Vmyes-te my spra-vim-sya)*
*Together we'll manage*

**–Ø –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –≥–æ—Ä–∂—É—Å—å —Ç–æ–±–æ–π**
*(Ya o-chen' gor-zhus' to-boy)*
*I'm very proud of you*

## Active Support

**–ß—Ç–æ —è –º–æ–≥—É —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã —Ç–µ–±–µ –ø–æ–º–æ—á—å?**
*(Chto ya mo-gu sdye-lat', chto-by te-bye po-moch'?)*
*What can I do to help you?*

**–•–æ—á–µ—à—å –ø–æ–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç—å –æ–± —ç—Ç–æ–º –∏–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ –ø–æ–±—ã—Ç—å –≤–º–µ—Å—Ç–µ?**
*Do you want to talk about it or just be together?*

**–°–∫–∞–∂–∏ –º–Ω–µ, —á—Ç–æ —Ç–µ–±–µ –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ**
*Tell me what you need*

## Specific Situations

### Grief
**–ú–Ω–µ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –∂–∞–ª—å**
*I'm so sorry*

**–Ø —Ä—è–¥–æ–º, —á—Ç–æ –±—ã –Ω–∏ —Å–ª—É—á–∏–ª–æ—Å—å**
*I'm here, no matter what*

### Stress
**–î—ã—à–∏ —Å–æ –º–Ω–æ–π**
*Breathe with me*

**–î–∞–≤–∞–π —à–∞–≥ –∑–∞ —à–∞–≥–æ–º**
*Let's take it step by step*

### Disappointment
**–Ø –∑–Ω–∞—é, –∫–∞–∫ –º–Ω–æ–≥–æ —ç—Ç–æ –¥–ª—è —Ç–µ–±—è –∑–Ω–∞—á–∏–ª–æ**
*I know how much this meant to you*

**–¢–µ–±–µ –Ω–µ –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ –≤—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞ –±—ã—Ç—å —Å–∏–ª—å–Ω—ã–º/—Å–∏–ª—å–Ω–æ–π**
*You don't always have to be strong*

## Physical Comfort

**–ò–¥–∏ —Å—é–¥–∞, –¥–∞–π —è —Ç–µ–±—è –æ–±–Ω–∏–º—É**
*Come here, let me hug you*

## Encouragement

**–¢—ã —Å–∏–ª—å–Ω–µ–µ, —á–µ–º –¥—É–º–∞–µ—à—å**
*You're stronger than you think*

**–Ø –≤–µ—Ä—é –≤ —Ç–µ–±—è**
*I believe in you*

## Being Present

**–¢–µ–±–µ –Ω–µ –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ –Ω–∏—á–µ–≥–æ –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç—å**
*You don't need to say anything*

**–Ø –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ —Ö–æ—á—É –±—ã—Ç—å —Ä—è–¥–æ–º**
*I just want to be near you*

Russian comfort reaches the *dusha*‚Äîthe very soul.

articles.title: Is French Hard? Honest Assessment
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Learning French as a couple can be one of the most romantic and rewarding adventures you'll embark on together. But let's address the elephant in the room: **Is French really hard to learn for English speakers?** The honest answer is nuanced, and we're here to give you the complete picture so you and your partner can make an informed decision about your French learning journey.

## The Reality: French Difficulty for English Speakers

According to the U.S. Foreign Service Institute, French is classified as a Category I language for English speakers, meaning it's among the **easier languages to learn**. However, "easier" doesn't mean "easy" ‚Äì it typically takes 600-750 class hours to reach proficiency.

<VocabCard
  word="facile"
  translation="easy"
  pronunciation="[fah-SEEL]"
  example="Le fran√ßais n'est pas toujours facile."
/>

### What Makes French Challenging?

Let's be honest about the hurdles you'll face together:

**1. Pronunciation and Accent**
French has sounds that don't exist in English, like the rolled "r" and nasal vowels. The good news? Practicing with your partner makes it fun and less intimidating.

**2. Grammar Complexity**
French grammar includes gendered nouns, complex verb conjugations, and agreement rules that can feel overwhelming at first.

<ConjugationTable
  verb="√™tre"
  meaning="to be"
  conjugations={[
    { "person": "Je", "word": "suis", "translation": "I am" },
    { "person": "Tu", "word": "es", "translation": "You are" },
    { "person": "Il/Elle", "word": "est", "translation": "He/She is" },
    { "person": "Nous", "word": "sommes", "translation": "We are" },
    { "person": "Vous", "word": "√™tes", "translation": "You are (formal)" },
    { "person": "Ils/Elles", "word": "sont", "translation": "They are" }
  ]}
/>

**3. Gendered Nouns**
Every noun in French is either masculine or feminine, affecting articles and adjectives.

| Gender | Article | Example | Translation |
|--------|---------|---------|-------------|
| Masculine | le/un | **le livre** (luh LEE-vruh) | the book |
| Feminine | la/une | **la maison** (lah may-ZOHN) | the house |

## What Makes French Easier Than You Think

**1. Shared Vocabulary**
English and French share thousands of words due to historical connections. Words like **restaurant**, **caf√©**, and **chocolat** are virtually identical!

<VocabCard
  word="restaurant"
  translation="restaurant"
  pronunciation="[res-toh-RAHN]"
  example="Nous d√Ænons au restaurant ce soir."
/>

**2. Logical Spelling System**
Unlike English, French spelling is relatively consistent. Once you learn the rules, you can often predict pronunciation.

**3. Cultural Motivation**
French culture ‚Äì from cuisine to cinema ‚Äì provides endless motivation for couples to continue learning together.

<CultureTip title="Romance in Learning" flag="üá´üá∑">
French is called the "language of love" for good reason. Learning romantic expressions together strengthens both your relationship and your language skills. Many couples find that practicing French pet names like "mon ch√©ri" (my darling) and "ma belle" (my beautiful) adds playful romance to their daily interactions.
</CultureTip>

## Couple Learning Strategies That Work

### 1. Daily French Conversations
Start each morning by greeting each other in French:

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Bonjour, mon amour"
  translation="Good morning, my love"
  pronunciation="[bon-ZHOOR, mon ah-MOOR]"
  context="A romantic way to start your day while practicing French"
/>

### 2. French Date Nights
Transform your regular date nights into French immersion experiences:
- Cook French recipes together while speaking only French
- Watch French movies with subtitles
- Visit French restaurants and practice ordering

### 3. Role-Playing Exercises
Practice real-life scenarios together:
- **Au caf√©** (at the caf√©): Take turns being the customer and server
- **√Ä l'h√¥tel** (at the hotel): Practice checking in during your future Paris trip
- **Au march√©** (at the market): Role-play buying ingredients

<VocabCard
  word="ensemble"
  translation="together"
  pronunciation="[ahn-SAHM-bluh]"
  example="Nous apprenons le fran√ßais ensemble."
/>

## Timeline: How Long Does It Really Take?

Here's a realistic timeline for English-speaking couples learning French together:

| Timeline | Level | What You Can Do |
|----------|-------|----------------|
| 3 months | Beginner | Basic greetings, ordering food, simple conversations |
| 6 months | Elementary | Discuss daily activities, express preferences |
| 1 year | Intermediate | Hold meaningful conversations, understand movies with subtitles |
| 2 years | Upper-Intermediate | Discuss complex topics, read French literature |

## Common Mistakes Couples Make

**1. Comparing Progress**
Everyone learns at different speeds. Celebrate individual victories rather than competing.

**2. Only Speaking English Together**
Make a pact to use French for specific activities or times of day.

**3. Perfectionism**
Mistakes are part of learning! Laugh at errors together and keep practicing.

<CultureTip title="French Patience" flag="üá´üá∑">
French culture values taking time to savor experiences, including language learning. Don't rush the process ‚Äì "petit √† petit, l'oiseau fait son nid" (little by little, the bird builds its nest). This French proverb reminds us that consistent, patient effort yields the best results.
</CultureTip>

## Making French Easier: Practical Tips

### 1. Use Cognates
Start with words that are similar in English and French:
- **Animal** [ah-nee-MAHL] (animal)
- **H√¥pital** [oh-pee-TAHL] (hospital)
- **Nature** [nah-TOOR] (nature)

### 2. Practice Pronunciation Together
Record yourselves speaking and compare to native speakers. Make it a fun challenge!

### 3. Create French Habits
- Change your phone's language to French
- Listen to French podcasts during commutes
- Follow French social media accounts

## The Verdict: Is French Hard?

**French is moderately challenging but absolutely achievable** for English-speaking couples. The key factors for success are:

1. **Consistency** over intensity
2. **Patience** with the learning process
3. **Support** from your partner
4. **Immersion** in French culture and media

The romantic aspect of learning French together actually makes it easier ‚Äì you have built-in motivation, practice partner, and cheerleader all in one!

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Nous r√©ussirons ensemble"
  translation="We will succeed together"
  pronunciation="[noo ray-oo-see-ROHN ahn-SAHM-bluh]"
  context="Perfect motivation for couples learning French"
/>

## Your French Learning Journey Starts Now

Remember, every francophone started as a beginner. The question isn't whether French is hard ‚Äì it's whether you're ready to embark on this beautiful journey together. With dedication, patience, and the right approach, you'll be saying **"Je t'aime"** [zhuh TEHM] (I love you) in French sooner than you think!

The hardest part about learning French isn't the grammar or pronunciation ‚Äì it's taking the first step. But you don't have to take it alone.

<CTA text="Ready to master French together?" buttonText="Start Learning Now" />

articles.title: Godmorgen og Godnat p√• Norsk: S√∏de Fraser til Din Partner
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

De f√∏rste og sidste ord p√• dagen er magiske. En s√∏d godmorgen p√• norsk kan starte dagen perfekt, og en k√¶rlig godnat sikrer s√∏de dr√∏mme. Kombiner med vores [norske k√¶lenavne](/learn/da/no/norwegian-pet-names-and-endearments/)!

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Good morning, my love"
  translation="Godmorgen, min elskede"
  pronunciation="gud mor-ning mai lav"
  context="Start dagen med k√¶rlighed"
/>

## Godmorgen Fraser

<VocabCard
  word="Good morning"
  translation="Godmorgen"
  pronunciation="gud mor-ning"
  example="Good morning, sweetheart!"
/>

| Norsk | Dansk | Udtale |
|---------|-------|--------|
| **Good morning** | Godmorgen | gud mor-ning |
| **Good morning, my love** | Godmorgen, min elskede | gud mor-ning mai lav |
| **Did you sleep well?** | Har du sovet godt? | did juu sliip wel? |
| **What a beautiful morning** | Sikke en smuk morgen | wot uh byu-ti-ful mor-ning |
| **Rise and shine!** | Op og hoppe! | raiz and shain! |

### S√∏de Morgenhilsner

- **Did you dream of me?** (Har du dr√∏mt om mig?) - "did juu driim ov mi?"
- **You're my first thought** (Du er min f√∏rste tanke) - "joor mai furst thot"
- **Coffee, darling?** (Kaffe, skat?) - "ko-fi, dar-ling?"
- **Good morning, sunshine** (Godmorgen, solskin) - "gud mor-ning, sun-shain"

<CultureTip flag="üá≥üá¥" title="Morgenkultur">
Engl√¶ndere starter ofte dagen med 'a cuppa' - perfekt tidspunkt for en k√¶rlig besked.
</CultureTip>

## Morgenmotivation

- **Have a good day** (Hav en god dag) - "hav uh gud dei"
- **You'll do great** (Du vil klare det fantastisk) - "juul duu greit"
- **I'm proud of you** (Jeg er stolt af dig) - "aim praud ov juu"
- **Good luck today** (Held og lykke i dag) - "gud lak tuh-dei"

## I L√∏bet af Dagen

<VocabCard
  word="Thinking of you"
  translation="Jeg t√¶nker p√• dig"
  pronunciation="thing-king ov juu"
  example="Just thinking of you."
/>

| Norsk | Dansk | Hvorn√•r |
|---------|-------|---------|
| **Thinking of you** | Jeg t√¶nker p√• dig | Midt p√• dagen |
| **I miss you** | Jeg savner dig | N√•r adskilt |
| **How's your day going?** | Hvordan g√•r din dag? | Eftermiddag |
| **See you soon** | Vi ses snart | F√∏r genforening |

## Godaften Fraser

- **Good evening** (Godaften) - "gud iiv-ning"
- **Finally home** (Endelig hjemme) - "fai-na-li houm"
- **I missed you** (Jeg har savnet dig) - "ai mist juu"
- **How was your day?** (Hvordan var din dag?) - "hau woz joor dei?"

## Godnat Fraser

<VocabCard
  word="Good night"
  translation="Godnat"
  pronunciation="gud nait"
  example="Good night, sleep tight."
/>

| Norsk | Dansk | Udtale |
|---------|-------|--------|
| **Good night** | Godnat | gud nait |
| **Good night, my love** | Godnat, min elskede | gud nait mai lav |
| **Sweet dreams** | S√∏de dr√∏mme | swiit driimz |
| **Sleep tight** | Sov godt | sliip tait |
| **See you tomorrow** | Vi ses i morgen | sii juu tuh-mo-rou |

### Romantiske Godnat-beskeder

- **You're my last thought** (Du er min sidste tanke) - "joor mai last thot"
- **Dream of me** (Dr√∏m om mig) - "driim ov mi"
- **A goodnight kiss** (Et godnat-kys) - "uh gud-nait kis"
- **I love you, goodnight** (Jeg elsker dig, godnat) - "ai lav juu gud-nait"

<CultureTip flag="üá≥üá¥" title="Godnat-traditioner">
Et godnat-kys og 'I love you' er den perfekte afslutning p√• dagen.
</CultureTip>

## S√∏vnrelaterede Fraser

| Norsk | Dansk | Udtale |
|---------|-------|--------|
| **I'm tired** | Jeg er tr√¶t | aim tai-urd |
| **I'm sleepy** | Jeg er s√∏vnig | aim slii-pi |
| **I can't sleep** | Jeg kan ikke sove | ai kant sliip |
| **I had a nightmare** | Jeg havde mareridt | ai had uh nait-mehr |
| **Let's take a nap** | Lad os tage en lur | lets teik uh nap |

## Weekend Morgen

- **Let's stay in bed** (Lad os blive i sengen) - "lets stei in bed"
- **A lazy morning** (En doven morgen) - "uh lei-zi mor-ning"
- **Shall we brunch?** (Skal vi brunche?) - "shal wii brunch?"
- **Come cuddle** (Kom og kram) - "kum ku-dul"

## Tekstbeskeder

### Morgenbeskeder
- **Good morning, sweetheart üíï** (Godmorgen, skat üíï)
- **Hope you have an amazing day** (H√•ber du har en fantastisk dag)
- **Thinking of you** (T√¶nker p√• dig)

### Aftenbeskeder
- **Looking forward to seeing you** (Gl√¶der mig til at se dig)
- **Almost home** (Snart hjemme)
- **Goodnight, sweet dreams üåô** (Godnat, dr√∏m s√∏dt üåô)

## Tips til Daglige Ritualer

1. **V√¶r konsekvent** - G√∏r det til en vane
2. **Varier fraserne** - Brug forskellige hver dag
3. **Tilf√∏j k√¶lenavne** - Det g√∏r det personligt
4. **Send beskeder** - N√•r I er adskilt
5. **V√¶r oprigtig** - Sig det med f√∏lelse

For flere romantiske fraser, se [norske romantiske fraser](/learn/da/no/norwegian-romantic-phrases-for-every-occasion/).

Disse daglige norske ritualer er sm√• k√¶rlighedserkl√¶ringer.

<CTA />

articles.title: Russiske Flirtes√¶tninger for Danskere
articles.content:
Russisk er et sprog fyldt med f√∏lelser og poesi. Russere udtrykker k√¶rlighed intenst og passioneret, og de rigtige ord kan virkelig g√∏re indtryk. L√¶r disse s√¶tninger for at vise din russisktalende partner, at du br√¶nder for dem.

## Russisk Romantik

Russere skelner skarpt mellem overfladiske bekendtskaber og dybe relationer. N√•r en russer √•bner sit hjerte for dig, er det for alvor. De forventer samme dybde og engagement til geng√¶ld.

## Det Kyrilliske Alfabet

Russisk bruger det kyrilliske alfabet. Her giver vi b√•de kyrillisk og translitteration for at hj√¶lpe dig.

## Grundl√¶ggende Komplimenter

### "–£ —Ç–µ–±—è –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤—ã–µ –≥–ª–∞–∑–∞" (U tebya krasiviye glaza)
**Udtale:** u ti-BJA kra-SI-vi-je gla-ZA

**Betydning:** Du har smukke √∏jne

En tidl√∏s kompliment. "–ö—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤—ã–π" (krasiviy) bruges om √¶stetisk sk√∏nhed.

### "–¢—ã –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤–∞—è/–∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤—ã–π" (Ty ochen' krasivaya/krasiviy)
**Udtale:** ti O-tjen kra-SI-va-ja/kra-SI-vij

**Betydning:** Du er meget smuk

Brug "–∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤–∞—è" til kvinder og "–∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤—ã–π" til m√¶nd.

### "–ú–Ω–µ –Ω—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—Å—è —Ç–≤–æ—è —É–ª—ã–±–∫–∞" (Mne nravitsya tvoya ulybka)
**Udtale:** mnje NRA-vit-sja tva-JA u-LIB-ka

**Betydning:** Jeg kan lide dit smil

Enkel og s√∏d. "–ù—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å—Å—è" bruges til at udtrykke, at man kan lide noget.

## Romantiske Udtryk

### "–Ø –ø–æ—Å—Ç–æ—è–Ω–Ω–æ –¥—É–º–∞—é –æ —Ç–µ–±–µ" (Ya postoyanno dumayu o tebe)
**Udtale:** ja pa-sta-JA-na DU-ma-ju a ti-BJE

**Betydning:** Jeg t√¶nker konstant p√• dig

En klassisk romantisk erkl√¶ring for n√•r forholdet udvikler sig.

### "–¢—ã –¥–µ–ª–∞–µ—à—å –º–µ–Ω—è —Å—á–∞—Å—Ç–ª–∏–≤—ã–º/—Å—á–∞—Å—Ç–ª–∏–≤–æ–π" (Ty delayesh' menya schastlivym/schastlivoy)
**Udtale:** ti DJE-la-je É mi-NJA  Ét Éas-LI-vim/ Ét Éas-LI-vaj

**Betydning:** Du g√∏r mig lykkelig

Brug "—Å—á–∞—Å—Ç–ª–∏–≤—ã–º" hvis du er mand, "—Å—á–∞—Å—Ç–ª–∏–≤–æ–π" hvis du er kvinde.

### "–ú–Ω–µ —Ç–∞–∫ —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–æ —Å —Ç–æ–±–æ–π" (Mne tak khorosho s toboy)
**Udtale:** mnje tak xa-ra- ÉO s ta-BOJ

**Betydning:** Jeg har det s√• godt med dig

Udtrykker velv√¶re og tilfredshed i den andens selskab.

## Mere Intense Udtryk

### "–¢—ã —Å–≤–æ–¥–∏—à—å –º–µ–Ω—è —Å —É–º–∞" (Ty svodish' menya s uma)
**Udtale:** ti SVO-di É mi-NJA s u-MA

**Bedeutning:** Du g√∏r mig vanvittig

Passioneret og intens ‚Äì typisk for russisk k√¶rlighedsudtryk.

### "–Ø –±–µ–∑ —Ç–µ–±—è –Ω–µ –º–æ–≥—É" (Ya bez tebya ne mogu)
**Udtale:** ja bjez ti-BJA nji ma-GU

**Betydning:** Jeg kan ikke v√¶re uden dig

En st√¶rk erkl√¶ring for dybt forelsket par.

## Invitationer

### "–•–æ—á–µ—à—å –≤—ã–ø–∏—Ç—å –∫–æ—Ñ–µ?" (Khochesh' vypit' kofe?)
**Udtale:** XO-t Ée É VI-pit KO-fje

**Betydning:** Vil du have en kop kaffe?

Afslappet og uforpligtende invitation.

### "–ú–æ–≥—É —è –ø—Ä–∏–≥–ª–∞—Å–∏—Ç—å —Ç–µ–±—è –Ω–∞ —É–∂–∏–Ω?" (Mogu ya priglasit' tebya na uzhin?)
**Udtale:** ma-GU ja pri-gla-SIT ti-BJA na U- íin

**Betydning:** M√• jeg invitere dig p√• aftensmad?

Mere formel og romantisk.

## K√¶rlige K√¶lenavne

### "–ú–∏–ª—ã–π/–ú–∏–ª–∞—è" (Miliy/Milaya)
**Udtale:** MI-lij/MI-la-ja

**Betydning:** Skat / S√∏de

Det mest almindelige russiske k√¶lenavn.

### "–õ—é–±–∏–º—ã–π/–õ—é–±–∏–º–∞—è" (Lyubimiy/Lyubimaya)
**Udtale:** lju-BI-mij/lju-BI-ma-ja

**Betydning:** Elskede

Meget k√¶rligt og brugt mellem etablerede par.

### "–°–æ–ª–Ω—ã—à–∫–æ" (Solnyshko)
**Udtale:** SOL-ni É-ka

**Betydning:** Lille sol

S√∏dt og varmt k√¶lenavn.

### "–ó–∞–π—á–∏–∫/–ó–∞–π–∫–∞" (Zaychik/Zayka)
**Udtale:** ZAJ-t Éik/ZAJ-ka

**Betydning:** Lille kanin

Meget popul√¶rt k√¶lenavn for begge k√∏n.

## Kulturelle Indsigter

**Blomster:** Giv altid et ulige antal blomster (lige antal er til begravelser). R√∏de roser er romantiske, gule kan betyde utroskab.

**Galanthed:** Russiske m√¶nd forventes at v√¶re galante ‚Äì √•bne d√∏re, b√¶re tasker, betale regningen.

**Familie:** N√•r en russer introducerer dig for sin familie, er det seri√∏st. Forbered dig p√• at blive "adopteret" ind i en stor, t√¶t familie.

**F√∏lelser:** Russere kan virke kolde udadtil, men de f√∏ler dybt. T√•lmodighed bel√∏nnes.

## Grammatiske Hints

Russisk har k√∏n og kasus:

- **Adjektiver √¶ndres:** -—ã–π/-–∏–π (maskulin), -–∞—è/-—è—è (feminin), -–æ–µ/-–µ–µ (neutrum)
- **–¢–∏ vs. –í—ã:** "–¢—ã" er uformelt/intimt, "–í—ã" er formelt. Skift til "—Ç—ã" n√•r I bliver t√¶ttere.

## Grundl√¶ggende Kyrillisk

Nyttige bogstaver at kende:

- –ê, –ï, –û: som p√• dansk
- –ò: som dansk "i"
- –£: som dansk "u"
- –ô: som dansk "j"
- –®: som "sh"
- –ß: som "tj"
- –Ø: som "ja"

## Afsluttende Ord

Russisk romantik er intens og oprigtig. N√•r du taler fra hjertet, vil din russiske partner m√¶rke det. V√¶r t√•lmodig, v√¶r √¶gte, og v√¶r klar til dyb k√¶rlighed.

–£–¥–∞—á–∏ –≤ –ª—é–±–≤–∏! (Held og lykke i k√¶rlighed!)

import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';

bryllupsrejsen ‚Äî —ç—Ç–æ –º–∞–≥–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–µ –≤—Ä–µ–º—è –¥–ª—è –º–æ–ª–æ–¥–æ–∂—ë–Ω–æ–≤. –ï—Å–ª–∏ –≤—ã –ø—É—Ç–µ—à–µ—Å—Ç–≤—É–µ—Ç–µ –≤ —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—É, –≥–¥–µ –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä—è—Ç –Ω–∞ –¥–∞—Ç—Å–∫–∏–π —è–∑—ã–∫–µ, –∏–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ —Ö–æ—Ç–∏—Ç–µ –¥–æ–±–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å —Ä–æ–º–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–∫–∏, –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä—è –Ω–∞ —è–∑—ã–∫–µ –≤–∞—à–µ–≥–æ –ø–∞—Ä—Ç–Ω—ë—Ä–∞, —ç—Ç–∏ —Ñ—Ä–∞–∑—ã —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞—é—Ç –≤–∞—à–µ rejsen –Ω–µ–∑–∞–±—ã–≤–∞–µ–º—ã–º.

–î–ª—è –ø–æ–≤—Å–µ–¥–Ω–µ–≤–Ω—ã—Ö —Ä–æ–º–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –≤—ã—Ä–∞–∂–µ–Ω–∏–π —Å–º–æ—Ç—Ä–∏—Ç–µ [—Ä–æ–º–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ —Ñ—Ä–∞–∑—ã –Ω–∞ –¥–∞—Ç—Å–∫–∏–π](/blog/ru/danish-romantic-phrases-for-every-occasion).

<PhraseOfDay
  word="bryllupsrejsen"
  translation="–º–µ–¥–æ–≤—ã–π –º–µ—Å—è—Ü"
  pronunciation="bryllupsrejsen"
  context="–°–∞–º–æ–µ —Ä–æ–º–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—á–Ω–æ–µ –ø—É—Ç–µ—à–µ—Å—Ç–≤–∏–µ –≤–∞—à–µ–π –∂–∏–∑–Ω–∏."
/>

## –û—Å–Ω–æ–≤–Ω–∞—è –ª–µ–∫—Å–∏–∫–∞ –¥–ª—è –ø—É—Ç–µ—à–µ—Å—Ç–≤–∏–π

–°—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—ã, –≥–¥–µ –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä—è—Ç –Ω–∞ –¥–∞—Ç—Å–∫–∏–π —è–∑—ã–∫–µ, –ø—Ä–µ–¥–ª–∞–≥–∞—é—Ç –º–Ω–æ–∂–µ—Å—Ç–≤–æ romantisk –Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–π –¥–ª—è bryllupsrejsen. –û—Ç –∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –≥–æ—Ä–æ–¥–æ–≤ –¥–æ –ø—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—Å–Ω—ã—Ö strand ‚Äî –µ—Å—Ç—å –≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç—ã –¥–ª—è –ª—é–±–æ–π –ø–∞—Ä—ã.
</CultureTip>

## –≠–∫—Å–∫—É—Ä—Å–∏–∏ –∏ –ø—Ä–∏–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è

## –ü–æ–∫—É–ø–∫–∞ —Å—É–≤–µ–Ω–∏—Ä–æ–≤
